labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

issues.title: TLS 1.3 ... or its successor
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
The draft currently mandates support for TLS 1.3 for new protocols.  This might be bad at the point that we decide to deprecate TLS 1.3.

Maybe this can say TLS 1.3 *or a higher TLS version*.

issues.title: split into two drafts
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body: The "other protocols" section should be its own draft, and sent to UTA

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Done, closing.

issues.title: "frozen" is not a great word
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body: Not getting new features is more accurate.

issues.title: Clarify this is just for TLS 1.2 proper, not DTLS 1.2
issues.author: JonathanLennox
issues.body:
Given the slow progress of implementations of DTLS 1.3, I think this draft needs to be clear that this feature freeze applies only to TLS 1.2 proper, not DTLS 1.2.

For example, I would be very sad if any new DTLS-SRTP protection profiles could only be negotiated with DTLS 1.3.

This may have implications for the IANA instructions section, for registries that are shared between the two protocols.

comments.author: JonathanLennox
comments.body: Perhaps more seriously (since I don't know of any proposed new DTLS-SRTP protection profiles at this time):  if DTLS 1.3 stacks don't reach maturity before PQ KEMs are ready for production, we're going to need PQ KEMs for DTLS 1.2 if we're going to protect WebRTC traffic from harvest-now-decrypt-later attacks.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
> ...we're going to need PQ KEMs for DTLS 1.2...

It doesn't look like that work is being done for (D)TLS 1.2.

The most recent update I know of is here:
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ar-pquip-pqc-engineers-02.html

from this WG:
https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/pquip/about/

comments.author: JonathanLennox
comments.body:
Well, hopefully then the need for PQ support will incentivize stack developers to work on DTLS 1.3, I guess...

Nonetheless it seems to me like DTLS 1.3 implementation and deployment definitely haven't reached the maturity point that TLS 1.3 has, to warrant declaring DTLS 1.2 frozen, unfortunately.

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body:
There's an active discussion on the TLS list (pardon me for linking to myself...):
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/PvBUJFCOyQZ1cD6StRJeda6pB_U/

You should probably contribute there if you feel strongly.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Both drafts now say "this is only about TLS, not DTLS."  Thanks for the feedback.  Closing.

issues.title: Since this modified RFC 9325 ...
issues.author: richsalz
issues.body:
From @stpeter email to the UTA WG: RFC 9325 (BCP195) says that new protocols must support TLS 1.2 and TLS 1.3. Since this document says MUST 1.3 and MAY 1.2, two things need to happen:

- This must be marked as updating 9325 and explain what the changes are;
- This must be part of BCP 195 and not informational.

More detaikls in Peter's email at https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/uta/jkj0nSxHybzX0KrDwYxgfYvxfAg/

comments.author: sayrer
comments.body: He's right about the markings. But, also, do it!

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: @sayrer we WILL do it, just opened this issue to make sure not to forget it :)

issues.title: Too many IANA registries frozen?
issues.author: davidben
issues.body:
This may just be a reading comprehension failure on my end. Section 5 says:

>  IANA will stop accepting registrations for any TLS parameters [[TLS13REG](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-rsalz-tls-tls12-frozen-02.html#TLS13REG)] except for the following:
>
> * TLS Exporter Labels
>
> * TLS Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation (ALPN) Protocol IDs

But several more registries mentioned in RFC 8447 will still be alive and well after TLS 1.2:

* TLS ExtensionType Values
* TLS Cipher Suites Registry
* TLS Supported Groups
* TLS Alerts Registry
* TLS Certificate Types

Though I'm also slightly unclear on which registries it means because 8447 just adds to or tweaks those registries, rather than defining them. Am I just misreading this? Maybe it'd be easier to instead explicitly write the registries we mean to close.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
The intent is to say: If you want to add new values for TLS 1.2 IANA will only allow them for those two specific registries.

There are doubtless better ways to say that.

comments.author: davidben
comments.body: Ah. It read to me like you wanted to close new registrations altogether, since TLS 1.2 and 1.3 share many of the same registries. Maybe we want to phrase it as saying that new registrations are allowed but they need to have some footnote? Or maybe we just require it in prose in the corresponding document? Cipher suite registrations are already partitioned by 1.2 and 1.3 but we don't reflect it in the registry.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: The 8447bis document adds the “Note” column that this document suggests be used.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: @davidben please see #13 and approve or suggest changes.

pulls.title: Clarify IANA considerations
pulls.author: richsalz
pulls.body:
David Benjamin pointed out the wording in IANA considerations is misleading.

Fixes: #10

comments.body: Does this mean that new TLS/DTLS-agnostic extensions should be defined TLS 1.3+ and DTLS 1.2+? That seems a bit weird. Or are we saying that TLS/DTLS-agnostic extensions should be (D)TLS 1.3+ by way of "For TLS 1.3 or later", while DTLS-only extensions are allowed to target DTLS 1.2 and don't need that note?
